verses.text: Then one of the seven angels who had the seven bowls came and spoke to me, saying, "Come, I will show you the judgment of the great prostitute who sits on many waters."
verses.comment: The 'great prostitute' is a symbol often linked to corrupt worldly powers and false religion, echoing the imagery found in Jeremiah 51:13 where Babylon sits by many waters. The angel's invitation emphasizes God revealing hidden spiritual truths through messengers.

verses.text: With her the kings of the earth committed immorality, and those living on the earth became drunk with the wine of her fornication."
verses.comment: Earthly rulers participate in her corruption, drawing away from true worship to spiritual adultery. The wine symbolizes seduction of the world, much like the Old Testament condemnation of idolatrous nations.

verses.text: So he carried me away in the Spirit into a wilderness, and I saw a woman sitting on a scarlet beast covered with blasphemous names, having seven heads and ten horns.
verses.comment: Being 'carried in the Spirit' mirrors prophetic visions in Ezekiel. The scarlet beast recalls Revelation 13, representing anti-divine powers. The woman allied with the beast represents a union of religious compromise and political power.

verses.text: The woman was dressed in purple and scarlet, adorned with gold, precious stones, and pearls, holding a golden cup in her hand full of abominations and the impurities of her sexual immorality.
verses.comment: Her lavish attire symbolizes worldly seduction and spiritual betrayal, relating closely to wealth and idol-worship imagery from Ezekiel and Daniel. The golden cup reflects spiritual corruption disguised as beauty.

verses.text: A name was written on her forehead: "Mystery, Babylon the Great, Mother of Prostitutes and of the Abominations of the Earth."
verses.comment: Babylon is a metaphor for perverted spiritual governance and opposition to God. The forehead marking echoes Ezekiel’s seal and is a direct contrast to those sealed by God in Revelation.

verses.text: I saw that the woman was drunk with the blood of the saints and with the blood of the witnesses of Jesus. And when I saw her, I was greatly astonished.
verses.comment: Her intoxication with martyrdom points to persecution of true believers, connecting martyrdom events narrated earlier in Revelation and Daniel's prophecies. The astonishment reflects the depth of spiritual opposition to Christ.

verses.text: But the angel said to me, "Why are you amazed? I will tell you the mystery of the woman and of the beast that carries her, which has the seven heads and ten horns."
verses.comment: The angel promises prophetic understanding, connecting details of the beast to Daniel and Revelation 13. The use of 'mystery' points to divine revelation and hidden spiritual realities.

verses.text: The beast that you saw was, and is not, and is about to come up out of the abyss and go to destruction. The inhabitants of the earth whose names have not been written in the Book of Life from the foundation of the world will be amazed when they see the beast, because it was, and is not, and will be present.
verses.comment: The beast’s paradoxical existence hints at continual deceptive powers. The Book of Life reference restates the distinction between God's elect and the deceived, echoing Psalms and earlier references in Revelation.

verses.text: This calls for a mind with wisdom: The seven heads are seven mountains on which the woman sits.
verses.comment: Seven mountains symbolize fullness and strength, often interpreted as both literal powers and spiritual symbolism of opposition to God’s kingdom. The call to wisdom accentuates the spiritual depth required for understanding prophecy.

verses.text: There are also seven kings: five have fallen, one is, and the other has not yet come; and when he comes, he must remain for a short time.
verses.comment: Here, the succession of kings aligns closely with Daniel’s visions of empires. ‘One is’ suggests spiritual application to contemporary circumstances of the writer, while anticipation of a future ruler maintains an eschatological tension.

verses.text: The beast that was and is not is an eighth, but belongs to the seven, and goes to destruction.
verses.comment: The cyclical nature of evil empires is shown: although they seem defeated, spiritual opposition persists until final judgment. There is an underlying message about divine sovereignty over history.

verses.text: The ten horns that you saw are ten kings who have not yet received a kingdom, but they receive authority as kings with the beast for one hour.
verses.comment: This refers to temporary alliances of world powers, as Daniel predicted. The brief duration suggests the fleeting nature of worldly rebellion against God.

verses.text: These are of one mind, and they give their power and authority to the beast.
verses.comment: The unity of evil forces against God’s authority echoes Psalm 2 and earlier apocalyptic events in Revelation. It reveals a counterfeit unity opposing the true unity of believers.

verses.text: These will wage war against the Lamb, and the Lamb will overcome them because He is Lord of lords and King of kings, and with Him are those who are called, chosen, and faithful."
verses.comment: The victorious Lamb is Christ, master of all, fulfilling Old Testament titles (Deut. 10:17). His followers’ election and faithfulness point to the importance of perseverance, sanctification, and wholehearted commitment to Christ’s calling.

verses.text: And he said to me, "The waters that you saw, where the prostitute sits, are peoples and multitudes and nations and languages."
verses.comment: Images of waters represent the vast reach of corrupt influence over all humanity, underscoring spiritual universality—both of the adversary and, ultimately, Christ’s kingdom (see Dan. 7:14 for the global scope of God’s reign).

verses.text: And the ten horns you saw, and the beast, will hate the prostitute; they will make her desolate and naked, eat her flesh, and burn her with fire.
verses.comment: Here, evil’s self-destruction is shown. God permits evil to turn on itself, exposing its emptiness and powerlessness—echoed in prophetic warnings of judgment against unfaithfulness in Ezekiel and Isaiah.

verses.text: For God has put it into their hearts to carry out His purpose by agreeing to give their kingdom to the beast until the words of God are fulfilled.
verses.comment: God’s sovereign control over all history is clear here: even wicked rulers unknowingly fulfill divine prophecy, much like how God used foreign powers in Isaiah and the Psalms for His greater purposes.

verses.text: And the woman whom you saw is the great city that has dominion over the kings of the earth."
verses.comment: The woman as ‘great city’ is a composite figure of worldly influence and fallen spirituality. This image recalls Babylon’s claim over the kings of the earth (Dan. 4:30). Ultimately, the passage calls believers to discernment and to allegiance with the true, divinely-established community, united in faith under Christ alone.
